node.title: The Tote Bag Competition is back this year!

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Tote Bag Competition is a month-long contest where individuals, groups and organizations compete to create the best donation package of essential items for the homeless. As they select the contents of their package, we want participants to reflect on the common challenges faced by the homeless community and ponder what donations would be most effective for addressing them. Ultimately, it will help to raise awareness about homelessness through an engaging community event. After submissions are judged, the winner will be announced at our Tote Bag Competition event in February 2023, where we will hand out a prize for the highest-scoring entry.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/blog/lhci-2022-bto-tote-bag-competition/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Last year, the 2021-2022 Tote Bag Competition gathered dozens of submissions from groups across Ontario","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Ultimately, Laurier’s Homeless Care Initiative (LHCI) won the top prize for their comprehensive care package which best addressed the challenges of the harsh winter weather. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"It is super easy to participate in this year's competition! Submissions are sent in as a short video at most 60 seconds long. You can make a care package bag out of common household items (clothing, hygiene products and blankets) and compile a submission video in as little as 15 minutes. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Interested in participating? ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/pages/2022-2023-tote-bag-competition"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Read our competition outline for formal guidelines and submission deadlines","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We hope to build on the success of our first competition to see more participants and more creative care package ideas this coming February! We look forward to seeing your awesome tote bags!","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

node.title: Carving pumpkins for a Halloween fundraiser

node.title: A letter to an individual experiencing homelessness

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"dgKZSdBlM2CePe3JSEBA2","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"To the individual in poverty and despair, ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"I know you’re hurting. Bleeding. Your spirit, limping from the ordeal you endure day after day without rest. The uncertainty that comes with not knowing the next time you’ll eat, the terrifying realization of having no choice except to sleep on the streets, the loss of dignity that accompanies an arduous job search —- it must be monumentally taxing for you to trudge on. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"I see your crestfallen face, the bloody pain that glistens in your eyes. I can taste the frigid gust that bites your mouth, freezing tongue as you lie outside on a winter night without anywhere to go. I hear your pained sobs, your pleads for love, survival, basic human necessities. I feel your despair, your gnashing of teeth, as you yearn for but only a glimmer of relief. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"I know I’m merely typing on a laptop at the moment, but I long to do something — anything to add a little sparkle to your day. Desireth me nothing more than to comfort you - hold your hands, give you my sandwich, whisper you sweet somethings that make you feel believed in. Anything to assuage the melancholies of a precious human being. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"And don’t you dare tell me that you aren’t precious. For precious are you as the most unblemished of gems. After all: money, mansions, emeralds – such all have a finite value. Conversely, people — their personalities, their strengths, their unique personas — human beings are invaluable. Infinite. Irreplaceable. No quantity of wealth can replace a living, breathing person who has the capacity to love, and be loved. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Poverty doesn’t make you any less of a human being. Hunger doesn’t make you any less of a human being. Despair doesn’t make you any less of a human being. You, me, 7 billion people — we are all capable of laughing, of crying, of feeling, of being moved to tears by a soulful song, of dancing our heart out to a catchy beat, of loving others with every muscle in our bodies. Is that not the very definition of human? ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Deserving are you of love, and kindness, and respect. Deserving are you of a friend who believes in you (that is, me), someone who is cognizant of the wells of fortitude your soul holds. No, cross that out — deserving are you of a community that believes in you, and one that treasures your humanity and your personhood. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Please remember that, okay? ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"May you heal, ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Su ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[],"nodeType":"hr"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Su is a member of the Blankets for T.O. chapter at the University of Toronto Scarborough. Writers wishing to contribute pieces to the Blankets for T.O. blog are free to ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/contact"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"contact us","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Credit of the photo used in this article goes to ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://unsplash.com/photos/R35zUpA9Mbw"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Mediamodifier on Unsplash","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

node.title: We donated care packages on the streets of downtown Toronto

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Blankets for T.O. went on a donation run on Sunday, June 26th, 2022 to hand out food packages for the homeless on the streets of Toronto.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Our day first started at Toronto Union Station. Members of the executive team were also joined by one of our general members. From there, we walked northwards towards Toronto City Hall and stopped by every homeless individual we found on the streets. We handed out donation packages, each containing water, snacks, fruit, and drink mixes for energy and vitamin C.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"11Pu7Idftt2TEfZNyaCeAi","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We also took the time to approach the homeless on the streets, trying to engage in courteous and genuine conversation with them to understand them as individuals. For those who agreed, we also captured pictures and videos.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Those who joined us on our donation run gave us new insights into homelessness, with one participant describing it as “eye-opening” and “humbling”. It also reinforced the goals that first motivated our executive team to dedicate themselves to the organization. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7FsPQYIEMiqf4vgLoht0bE","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"One executive team member described the experience with the realization that “each homeless individual has faced and continues to face unique challenges mentally, physically, and emotionally. Homelessness is not a small issue that can be fixed with some glue. Hence, we, [as] citizens of the country and members of society, need to push for the right homelessness laws and ultimately build a system that caters to individual needs in order to eradicate this issue.”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Another wrote that “joining BTO and participating in this donation was an opportunity for me to do something, to get out there and bring attention to a crisis that has become far too normalized within our society. This will not solve all problems, but the more people see homelessness as a human rights issue and not something they ‘did to themselves,’ the more chances we have of creating long-term and lasting change.”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"See below for some of our photos from that day. Follow us on social media in the coming weeks for videos! We encourage our general members to join us on these donation runs in the future to take part in this enriching experience.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5TVyYNGbcHsFeLMizcTxEG","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

node.title: Public transit and homelessness

richTextBody.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"rQrb9czOO2UBD1EfxgHIz","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}},"content":[]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What role does public transit play in Toronto?","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" We all know that effective public transit infrastructure is key to big cities by providing sustainable, efficient, and affordable transportation, especially to those whose lives would otherwise be overburdened with the high costs of car ownership. Fortunately, transit in Toronto consistently ranks highly among North American cities, and the Toronto Transit Commission (TTC) was even ranked the top North American transit agency in 2017 [1]. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","data":{"uri":"https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ttc-operators-petition-homelessness-unhoused-people-government-help-1.5939862"},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In a 2021 petition, TTC operators argued that it should do more to address the rise in homelessness over recent years","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"text","value":" [2], proposing many effective solutions. In this short article, we give an overview of the role of public transit for homeless individuals. Additionally, we look into how other North American transit agencies have handled homelessness on their systems.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Among Toronto’s homeless population, one study found that public transit is ranked as one of the most common modes of transportation reported in surveys, second only to walking and just above cycling [3]. Among the most common reasons for trips reported visiting friends or family, accessing medical care, going to food pantries, commuting to and from shelters, and going for job searches and interviews [3,4]. The necessity of transport means that shelters benefit immensely from having good transit access. The need to assess and address the needs of this community, and other demographics suffering from poverty, has been recognized by numerous transit agencies and municipal departments. However, proper assessment of this group with traditional methods, such as surveys and record-keeping, proves uniquely difficult since some may lack a dedicated phone number or permanent address, and may move around numerous shelters or social services [5]. In surveys across American transit agencies, 73% believed that ridership is impacted by homelessness and 68% acknowledged responsibility in working with the homeless population [6]. Among the agencies surveyed, many cited a lack of funding for addressing the relevant issues appropriately [6]. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"With regards to transit affordability, recommendations to government institutions to promote inclusiveness and equal opportunity have included the subsidization of fares, such as the one put forth in Minnesota [7]. Transit agencies in Seattle, Portland, and San Francisco offer discount fares to unhoused passengers [8]. In Toronto, studies and proposals in 2014-2015 by the city council resulted in the creation of the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","data":{"uri":"https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/employment-social-support/support-for-people-in-financial-need/assistance-through-ontario-works/transit-discount/"},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Fair Pass Transit Discount Program","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"text","value":" [9]. Rolled out in 2018, it provides discounts to fares for eligible groups, including those on Ontario Works (OW) or living in subsidized housing [9]. When Blankets for T.O. talked with shelters and homeless individuals on the street about what essential items are in need, public transit fares have come up a few times as helpful items for donation. In response, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/blog/december-donations-downtown"},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"we gave out Presto fare cards during a donation run last year in downtown Toronto","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As we look across various transit agencies, we should note how each agency interacts with the homeless community, especially when individuals take up temporary residence in public transit spaces. In this dialogue, it is important to acknowledge that homeless individuals are not a monolithic group, as each will be varying personal challenges and unique sets of circumstances with regards to their financial situation, employment status, physical and mental health, and so forth. Thus, homeless individuals will utilize public transport infrastructure in different ways and would benefit from different methods of outreach. Studies in the UK, Germany and the United States have identified that a sizable portion of homeless individuals spend their nights on buses and trains, with many citing disagreement with shelter guidelines or lack of shelter availability [6]. If you are a Toronto resident, you may have seen homeless individuals resting in subway train carriages or in station corridors. Different agencies have tackled these occurrences differently. When we review approaches across North America, approaches can generally be categorized into punitive and outreach responses [6]. Punitive measures to homelessness on transit may involve a transit agency instructing workers to perform occasional sweeps to remove homeless individuals from transit areas or to order homeless individuals off of vehicles once they have reached the final stop [6]. These are made possible by the creation of local ordinances which may prohibit loitering and sleeping at transit stations, thus allowing authorities to give fines, make arrests and confiscate property [6]. To the same effect, agencies may also employ “hostile architecture” by deliberately designing seats and station surfaces to be uncomfortable to sleep on [6]. Critics argue that these approaches merely displace homelessness to other places by unfairly criminalizing and avoiding efforts to resolve it [6]. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"4fTnpJzGzD4zwhDRPoYar2","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}},"content":[]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Not all measures are of a punitive nature, for there are outreach programs in place in various systems. In New York City, the transit authority has allowed city services to organize shuttles that bring homeless individuals from subway line termini to local shelters [8]. Additionally, trained outreach workers from local nonprofits may be present at these stations, enabling them to quickly set up the appropriate services and accommodations at the station instead of the shelter [8]. In Denver, social workers and clinicians accompany security staff when transit police identify riders in need [8]. A review of approaches across American transit agencies suggests that those better able to separate enforcement and outreach activities achieve better outcomes [8]","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"These approaches are similar to those proposed by the aforementioned petition by TTC operators [2,10]. That petition supports the establishment of mobile response teams for harm reduction and overdose prevention, regular patrol of TTC vehicles by social outreach workers, and introduction of crisis workers to educate TTC operators on how to handle interactions with the homeless community [10]. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","data":{"uri":"https://www.ttc.ca/news/2017/June/TTC-named-North-Americas-best-transit-agency-for-2017"},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The petition has gained over 1000 signatures on change.org","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Public transit in Toronto, just like in any other city, will remain an integral part of our local communities by offering accessible, reliable and sustainable mobility. It works to provide residents with equal access to education, employment, and city services. All of these are key to promoting equal opportunity and addressing long-standing socioeconomic inequities. Investments into public transit not only help homeless communities, but also net huge benefits for youth, new residents, immigrants, refugees, low-income households, and individuals with disabilities. We all benefit from world-class transit service in Toronto and thus we should all work to advocate for these groups in need. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"References","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"ordered-list","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Toronto Transit Commission. node.title: The role of supportive housing in breaking mental health barriers

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Listeners to the most recent episode of our official podcast, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/podcasts"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Beyond the Blankets","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":",","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" may have already heard of the connection between Professor Steve Joordens' first-year psychology course and Desmond Rowley, a staff member at Houselink and Mainstay Community Housing. Don’t be worried if you haven’t listened to it, because in this article we take a deeper dive into how Houselink tackles homelessness with its emphasis on mental health and addiction treatment. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"People like Desmond Rowley may not be whom you would first think of when talking about supportive housing in Toronto. Having studied computer science and business administration, Desmond left his investment brokerage firm position of three years after beginning to feel unfulfilled in that position. He said that he had a strong desire to find a completely new adventure in his life, preferably one where he would be helping people and giving back. In his resulting journey, he joined a youth shelter to implement new programs, helped struggling individuals to find affordable housing, and gained experience across maintaining multiple recreation venues. Today, he is a Program Manager at ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.hlms.ca/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Houselink and Mainstay Community Housing","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", a local charitable organization providing supportive housing and mental health services to struggling individuals in Toronto.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As the largest non-profit supportive housing organization in Toronto, Houselink and Mainstay Community Housing acknowledges the importance of housing in one’s life. The organization's roots date back to the 1970’s, when deinstitutionalization resulted in new demand for the housing system to support individuals that were recently released from psychiatric institutions. Today, the organization houses about 1120 individuals across more than 60 locations, while providing programs for mental illness, substance use, skills development, eviction prevention, recreation, and countless others. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The organization's programs are heavily structured around enabling individuals to overcome their personal struggles to unlock their true potential. It first starts with providing affordable housing, which provides a strong foundation for individuals to seek growth and success. Houselink follows a “housing first” approach, which removes some stringent criteria involving substance use and mental health treatment imposed by other services that would traditionally make many homeless individuals ineligible. In one study, researchers at the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH) and St. Michael’s Hospital studied the efficacy of the \"housing first\" approach in Toronto, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanpsy/article/PIIS2215-0366(19)30371-2/fulltext"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"and found that it allowed individuals to become better able to secure and maintain housing","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Furthermore, Houselink’s Frontline Supportive Housing Workers help individuals maintain housing by connecting them with opportunities, counselling, and healthcare treatment. A important step in preventing homelessness is finding appropriate employment, which can be extremely difficult for individuals afflicted with certain mental illnesses (","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"try quizzing yourself with the embedded question below","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"!). Their supportive employment program can help individuals to eventually become receptionists, couriers, landscapers, cooks, painters, and much more. This support allows tenants to find stable and fulfilling lives for themselves. Thus, it is no wonder that their work in supporting individuals with mental illness has helped to prevent countless individuals from facing chronic homelessness. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.hlms.ca/apply-for-housing/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Individuals wishing to apply to Houselink’s services can learn more about their eligibility criteria and application process here","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"46EtMEGsNZExQShgzliVJX","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Recently, students at the University of Toronto Scarborough were introduced to Houselink by Professor Steve Joordens through a ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9s2droIvZyY"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"collaboration","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" which saw first-year psychology students make public service announcements and other forms of digital media to dispel common homelessness myths. Groups with the top submissions were then given the opportunity to work with Houselink and have their work posted to social media. In total, over 400 projects were created by over 1700 students! Blankets for T.O. was fortunate enough to cross paths with Steve Joordens in our second episode ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Beyond the Blankets","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/podcasts/beyond-the-blankets/discussing-the-myths-with-professor-steve-joordens/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Have a listen on our podcast page if you have not yet listened to it!","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Through this look at Houselink and Mainstay Community Housing, we hope that you have new insight into how existing organizations within Toronto are tackling homelessness and mental health. Maybe Desmond's personal journey has opened your eyes into what initiatives you can get involved in and how you can help local communities, irrespective of your academic background. Let us know if you want any other local organizations covered on our blog!","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

childMarkdownRemark.html: We dive into how Houselink tackles homelessness by addressing mental illness and enabling tenants to unlock their true potential.

In fact, there are currently five chapters at various Ontario universities which are all in the middle of organizing events, planning fundraisers, making donations and founding new social media communities!","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We have helped establish ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Blankets for Hamilton","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" at McMaster University, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Blankets for Oshawa ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"at Ontario Tech University, and ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Blankets for London","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" at Western University. Additionally, there is now a Blankets for T.O. chapter at the University of Toronto, St. George Campus. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A list of all these chapters, as well as links to their social media and membership forms, are posted on our website here.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/chapters"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Our expansion out from our founding chapter at the University of Toronto Scarborough means that our movement will be able to address homelessness in many more communities province-wide. These chapters will have a better grasp of local homelessness issues, a closer reach to homeless support systems, and an opportunity to build strong connections with local communities and public figures. Students at schools with a Blankets for T.O. chapter can look into joining them as a member which will allow you to enter a community of like-minded students, attend their events, and support their initiatives. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These new chapters have already started to make donations and build their own communities. Blankets for London made its first donation earlier this year! They gave 50 blankets to the Unity Project, a local homeless shelter. Follow these chapters on social media to keep updated with opportunities to join their teams, attend their events, or make donations!","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Don't see a chapter in your local community or at your local university? Want to help start and lead a chapter? Reach out to ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Blankets for T.O.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://blanketsforto.ca/contact"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and we would be happy to offer you help and resources for you to set up a new chapter!","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

node.title: General Members' Blog

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Apart from the mission we continuously work towards at Blankets for Toronto, we also want to shed some light on our amazing community of General Members! Our Members work towards amplifying the message of BTO and get a chance to volunteer as well. Most of the content is written by our Executive Team; however, we wanted to know what our General Members think of our mission and the stigmas around homeless. The first question we asked our Members was regarding their definition of homeless. Here are some of our Members’ excellent responses:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Gabilan says:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" “Homelessness is when someone is out of a home and could be because of many possible reasons. Homelessness can happen to anyone and one person experiencing it can impact many others.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Diane says:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" “I would define homelessness as the lack of safe and secure housing to support an individual or family. It can result from unaffordable housing but also unemployment and low income. They may also be experiencing poor health and inadequate nutrition. Multiple social determinants of health play a role. “","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Cafoor says","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":": “I would define homelessness as the inability to access the basic need of shelter. Shelter is vital to human survival and the absence of it renders an individual homeless. Homelessness is a huge problem in today's society due to an increase in world population and a reduction in government funding to combat that problem.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"From the above responses, we can see our members sharing the general sentiment of homelessness being the lack of a ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"home","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" which is something that is essential as a home is what encapsulates both our physical and emotional needs. As another one of our members, Katherine, beautifully said: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"“Being homeless is not having somewhere warm and safe to retire to when the sun sets. It's not having a place to call your own, even though we all deserve food, water, and shelter.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We followed up with a question regarding the negative stigmas around homeless and why they exist. Our Members brilliantly encapsulated the stereotypes persistent in society:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Katharine said:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" “The homeless are often looked down upon as \"lazy\" because they don't have the money to support themselves. Homelessness is not a choice, it is something some people struggle with when they are not given the same opportunities as others in society.”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Gabilan says: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"“In my opinion, there have been people who threatened and abused unhoused people with their thoughts and stereotypes. Phrases that I’ve heard focus the spotlight around how unhoused people have struggled with drug addiction and alcoholism. These concepts have been commonly put together in sentences, but without the acknowledgment of possible root problems to such. This common idea has also been placed against those who have been unhoused and haven't struggled with such habits.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Qyunh Nhi says: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"“I think there is a social stigma placed on homelessness, as homeless individuals are regarded as being \"lazy\" and \"unambitious\" and these qualities have resulted in these individuals being homeless. This could not be further from the truth as in most situations people that are stuck in the cycle of poverty are helpless and there appears to be no way out for them. For instance, if someone is born into a poor family it is very difficult for them to obtain a good education and eventually land a good job, this renders them unable to afford a home or food in most cases.”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The next question we asked our members was to suggest their opinions on how homeless can be tackled in our society. We received a handful of insightful responses:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Katharine says:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" “In my opinion, homelessness should be tackled in a non-judgemental way. We should come together to help our friends who aren't being given the necessities for survival and share what we have with them to better their lives.”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Gabilan suggests: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"“A better shelter system in my opinion is needed, as some people may even avoid places offering shelter due to the problems that can arise from being in there. Offering consistent therapy and rehabilitation services in-shelter is much needed. Furthermore, a consistent platform (which has been seen) for youth experiencing homelessness is the best possible solution to continue to enforce.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Diane says:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" “I think a root cause of homelessness is income. In one of my classes, I learned that Ontario conducted a Basic Income pilot project. Basic income is a payment given to people that ensures a minimum income level, regardless of employment status. It was a success! It promoted better health for people. These people also reported a more positive outlook on life. They were able to use the money toward their goals and aspirations, such as furthering their education. Overall, this project had a positive impact on people’s lives! “ ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Our Members touched on the crucial systematic measures that are needed when tackling homelessness: shelter systems and income. It is amazing to see how our members tried applying what they’ve learnt to come up with brilliant suggestions to combat homelessness! ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Our last question to our Members was to recount an experience when they happened to encounter a homeless individual, and some were more than happy to delve into the details behind their experience. Our Members also suggested ways to get homeless individuals more involved in the community! ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Diane recounted: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"“Growing up, my family would go to homeless shelters to provide meals. I would help serve food items. To me, the people at the shelters seemed like normal people with their own stories (some more friendly than others). I was young and could not quite understand why they were in this position. I remember being sad but motivated to give back to my community.“","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Cafoor says:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" “I have encountered a homeless person and the experience taught me a lot. I saw a man sitting outside a cafe holding a sign that read \" you can help change my life.\" In that particular moment it made me realize that any act of charity no matter how small can have a significant impact on someone. “","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Maya says: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"“Since many are on their own, I believe the first step is to engage with them and have a conversion about their day, stories, etc. This might make them feel like someone actually cares rather than people constantly walking by them. If a person has the money and can afford buying a couple of groceries for them or taking them to get a haircut, this could go a long way. “","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"These responses truly show how much our Members reflected on their experiences. It also shows how homeless individuals can be in this situation due to systematic failures, as they are also just like us and share the same emotions. Our Members’ experiences also highlight the immense effect a helping gesture can make, and we at Blankets for Toronto are always more than willing to accept members who are willing to donate to our cause! ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

node.title: We donated 100 care packages to Toronto shelters!

richTextBody.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5We0wL5KYt7vnTuL6AejUz","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In less than a month, Blanket for T.O.'s January Blanket Drive raised over $2250 in donations to help Toronto’s homeless. It was heartwarming and touching to see how many donors pitched into this fundraiser, and it completely shattered our expectations for this initiative. Since the conclusion of the fundraiser, our executive team has been busy organising the distribution of these funds in order to make the most out of this. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"With the funds received, we purchased essential supplies and packaged them into 100 care packages for donation to shelters within Toronto. Each care package contained a pair of gloves, a hat, a scarf, a pair of wool socks, pairs of hand and feet warmers, a rain poncho and a thermal blanket. All items were handed out in waterproof and portable drawstring bags. We chose these items because they will offer the best comfort and warmth to the homeless this winter.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We donated these care packages to two shelters, with each receiving 50. The first site was the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Homes First Better Living Centre Shelter","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://homesfirst.on.ca/better-living-centre/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", located in downtown Toronto with a capacity of 175 residents. Homes First is a non-profit housing provider which runs numerous shelters across the Greater Toronto Area, collectively housing more than 1500 individuals each night through their emergency shelter services. They also provide meal programs, community engagement opportunities and 1-on-1 assistance programs. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Learn more about Homes First through their website","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://homesfirst.on.ca/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The second shelter we donated to was a Family Residence site located in Scarborough and run by the Shelter, Support and Housing Administration. This shelter can house 52 families and offers children and youth programs, pregnancy support, counselling, and employment workshops. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read more about this shelter and other city-operated sites in Toronto on their website","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/community-partners/emergency-shelter-operators/about-torontos-shelter-system/see-our-shelters/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Thank you to everyone who donated to the fundraiser and shared it with others! We at Blankets for T.O. are so grateful for your generosity, and we are sure that the shelters and homeless individuals that received these care packages will be as well! Additionally, as we raise awareness for causes of homelessness, including discrimination, systemic inequalities, unaffordable housing and inadequate support systems, we hope that we can build a strong and resilient community to tackle homelessness.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"4zsUl6VDAQp8aAmTmupbRo","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

node.title: Anti-Homeless Architecture in Toronto

richTextBody.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"If you go for walks on the regular and take a break on a bench, you may have noticed that it has an armrest in the middle of it. It may feel nice to take a quick break and rest your arms, but this is not for your convenience nor comfort. This design is actually known as ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"hostile architecture","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", also called ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"anti-homeless architecture","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"53GQw9K66PnvfpICMloRMd","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In order to prevent homeless individuals from finding a comfortable place to sleep, these hostile features in public spaces restrict a person’s ability to lay down. Examples of anti-homeless architecture include concrete spikes underneath an underpass or entrance to a building, slanted benches, street dividers, and raised grate covers. These designs only serve the purpose of keeping homeless people off of street benches and other public areas to avoid seeing them in public. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"However, this type of architecture is rampant within the city of Toronto. Not only does this architecture negatively impact and target those who are homeless, it also makes it difficult for individuals with disabilities, the elderly, and young children to use public spaces. Hostile architecture only serves for protection of property and order maintenance - it harms those that society has deemed to be vulnerable, and rather than addressing lack of affordable housing and how inaccessible some public places are to people with disabilities, this architecture merely serves the purpose of shunning them. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Overall, instead of addressing these social issues in our society, the city has instead chosen the easier route of trying to hide homeless individuals from sight. Hostile architecture does not serve the public good - rather, it harms those most vulnerable in society by forcing them out of sight, as well as making it difficult for disabled people, the elderly, and young children to use public spaces. These spaces should be accessible to everyone, more now than ever due to the COVID-19 pandemic, since shelters are finding themselves overburdened as a result of strict capacity limits. Next time you are out for a walk, try and spot things that might be considered hostile architecture to see how common it is in your own neighbourhood. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"xrtrmDEioInJUT8ItiTJN","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"References and Further Reading","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"https://interestingengineering.com/15-examples-of-anti-homeless-hostile-architecture-that-you-probably-never-noticed-before","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://interestingengineering.com/15-examples-of-anti-homeless-hostile-architecture-that-you-probably-never-noticed-before"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"https://locallove.ca/life/unsung-hero-toronto-housing-advocate-aiko-ito/#.Yfg1bfXMKu5","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://locallove.ca/life/unsung-hero-toronto-housing-advocate-aiko-ito/#.Yfg1bfXMKu5"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"https://locallove.ca/issues/a-major-urban-design-trend-is-making-toronto-less-liveable/#.Yfg4WvXMKu5","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://locallove.ca/issues/a-major-urban-design-trend-is-making-toronto-less-liveable/#.Yfg4WvXMKu5"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"https://locallove.ca/life/what-to-donate-to-homeless-shelters-and-what-to-skip/#.Yfg4YfXMKu5","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://locallove.ca/life/what-to-donate-to-homeless-shelters-and-what-to-skip/#.Yfg4YfXMKu5"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

node.title: Impact of COVID on homelessness

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The pandemic has had a drastic impact on everyone: students, educators, businesses, and jobs. However, there is one community that has been the most affected, but is often overlooked - the homeless. Homelessness was already on the rise since before the pandemic, but ever since late 2019, homelessness rates have risen dramatically. It was reported that during the harsh winters of January 2021, there were an additional ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"30,000","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" cases of bankruptcy and homelessness reported.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Every year, an estimated 235,000 Canadians find themselves homeless. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"These Canadians are among the most vulnerable, with no practical option to adopt social distancing in order to avoid contracting COVID-19, which adds to the list of reasons why homelessness is a national emergency. Moreover, according to a study done by Lucie Richard, recent homeless individuals are more susceptible to COVID hospitalizations, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"10 times more likely","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" to get administered in an intensive care unit, and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"5 times more likely ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"to die within 21 days of a positive test. Dr. Richard’s research also found that with Ontario’s increased frequency of testing, the homeless population had 75% more positive tests than the population with housing. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Although the government has tried to provide these vulnerable communities with shelters, there has been less effort made to ensure social distancing, and according to a study done by Dr. Salimah Shariff, the high population density and morbidity of these shelters have put these individuals at a higher risk. While most people advocate for the increase of shelters for the homeless during these harsh times, Dr. Andrew Boozary, the Executive Director of Social Medicine at the University Health Network says otherwise. According to him, the air circulation and living conditions of these shelters are extremely formidable, and it would be better for the homeless community to take refuge in tents. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"One of the solutions to this problem is the potential increase in hotel recovery sites being set up in some municipalities. According to Boozary, housing and health go hand in hand as providing appropriate separated refuge has become a mandate in such conditions. Another important part of bridging this gap is to make homeless people feel welcome by creating trust between them and the communities that assist them, and that is exactly what we strive to do here at Blankets for Toronto.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

childMarkdownRemark.html: Homelessness has been on the rise since the pandemic, and it is time we shed some light on this community and try to raise their concerns.

node.title: Laurier HCI wins the 2022 BTO Tote Bag Competition

richTextBody.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"4bl4fKX3TGh2wYjbCyxYT4","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Groups from all across Canada attended Blankets for T.O.’s first Tote Bag Competition, held virtually on December 27th over Zoom. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In the Tote Bag Competition, participating groups are asked to design a tote bag which would serve as a care package donatable to a homeless individual. They were then tasked with presenting their tote bag in a short video, which could be shared on social media, and during the virtual event on December 27th.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The goal of the Tote Bag Competition was to spread awareness about the necessities and issues that homeless individuals face. To make a great tote bag, we encouraged groups to reach out to their local homeless shelters and do their own independent research into what supplies would be most appreciated by the homeless community. By opening the competition to groups from various universities and provinces, we aimed to bring attention to homelessness issues to a much wider audience.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We received submissions from a diverse range of student associations and organizations located at universities from across Canada, including the University of Toronto, University of Ottawa, York University, University of Western Ontario and Wilfrid Laurier University. Each group made wonderful videos introducing their tote bag:","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6ql0RAQxp25WDLWjDAUIB5","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In the run-up to the virtual event, Blankets for T.O. even received press coverage in the Toronto Star! Readers would have seen the article written by our very own Mei Ling Chow (BTO Director of Finance) and Zaynab Azeem (BTO First Year Representative). The article is available online ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"here","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.thestar.com/local-toronto-scarborough/opinion/2021/12/18/blankets-for-toronto-has-homelessness-covered.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" if you want a light three minute read. We also used the hashtag #carepackagecascade to promote the event on social media.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Submissions were scored following four categories: Item Quality, Creativity, Usefulness and Presentation. We valued submissions that showed effort in selecting high quality items that would be practical for homeless individuals. Judges also valued submissions showing creative and innovative ideas on how care packages can address daily needs and key necessities.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"With the tote bags and videos scored by the judges at Blankets for T.O., winners of the competition were announced at the end of the virtual event after presentations from every participant.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Congratulations to ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Laurier Homeless Care Initiative (LHCI) ","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"for winning the competition with their high quality, expansive and well thought-out care package!","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" For their win, they will receive a $500 prize that will go towards an initiative of their choosing. Additionally, we will be working with Laurier HCI to incorporate their items into new care packages for distribution in 2022. Second place, as well as its $250 prize, was secured by ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Olive Mission,","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for their care package which was made with direct consultation to local groups. Finally, third place was secured by ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Scar Robo","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for their skillful use of poetry in their video to present a well-rounded care package. Their organization will be given a $100 prize towards an initiative of their choice.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Thank you to all the participants of the Tote Bag Competition and all the attendees of the virtual event. It wouldn’t have been such a great success if these groups did not take time out of their busy schedules to put together a submission for the event. Also, thank you to everyone that shared, commented and liked the event on social media, as you supported your clubs through the Tote Bag Competition. This event is an important stepping stone for Blankets for T.O. in addressing the homelessness crisis in the GTA, and we hope to organize collaborations with other student groups in the future!","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

node.title: Myths and facts about homelessness

richTextBody.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"QVrLqzBfqFzmNj6zP2Sbs","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To get into the myths of homelessness, we first need to define what homelessness is. According to the Library of Parliament, homeless is divided into three broad terms:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Absolute homelessness: This is a narrow term that includes people who live on the streets or in emergency shelters.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Hidden or concealed homelessness: This term falls in the middle of the continuum and includes people living without a place of their own. This could include a car, with family or a long-term institution.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Relative homelessness: This falls on the other end of the continuum and is a broad category covering those who live in a house but live in substandard shelters, or may be at risk of losing their house.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"ordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To fully comprehend the umbrella term that is ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"homelessness","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", it is best to think of it as a pyramid in which homelessness is the tip of the iceberg. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"According to various organizations, for every homeless person visible on the street, there are four whose homelessness is concealed.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Around 250,000-300,000 Canadians suffer from homelessness every year, and almost 25,000-30,000 bear the consequences of homelessness on any given night.","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Since a substantial part of our community is facing this problem, it is important we address some myths and make it our job to educate ourselves more on the issue.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"The most prominent stereotype imposed on the homeless is that the majority of them abuse drugs and alcohol","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". This, as a matter of fact, is entirely false as statistics show only about 20-40% of the homeless community has a substance abuse history/problem. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Oftentimes, substance abuse is more so a coping mechanism or response to homelessness as they are exposed to more dealers and users of the substance","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Another stereotype imposed on homeless people is them being criminals.  This mainly happens because most of the homeless’ daily activities are criminalized such as getting arrested for minor offences like trespassing, littering and loitering. The next big claim is that the homeless people chose this life because of their bad choices. We have all made mistakes at some point in our lives; however, the fall to homelessness comes more as a direct result of one losing their job, being a victim to an illness, experiencing an unfortunate accident, or falling into debt. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"We have all heard this one: “They just need to get a job”. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A good portion of homeless people are working, but they simply cannot afford to pay rent. Moreover, most of the job listings require a stable housing, address and proper clothing, which makes getting a job much harder for the homeless. Another stereotype is that the homeless choose to live in unsanitary conditions . When people are conditioned to living outside, they are automatically in a place where there is no daily disposal for bodily functions, no set place to dispose of trash, nor containers to store food.  The last myth we will be discussing is the notion that there are plenty of services and support for the homeless. While this stands true, it only works in the short-term, there are individuals seeking long-term solutions to get out of the cycle of homelessness. It is integral we shed light on the need for more affordable housing and the need to confront the rising criminalization of homelessness which inhibits this community from receiving the permanent shelter that they need.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

childMarkdownRemark.html: We discuss some common stereotypes revolving around the homeless community and debunk some major myths in the community.

node.title: Homelessness and the Law

richTextBody.raw:
{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"embedded-asset-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"29FxhdvUA6Y3kzAMDsKLSl","type":"Link","linkType":"Asset"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Earlier this year, Quebec Premier François Legault said he expected people living on the street to abide by the province's curfew. The imposed four-week overnight curfew saw Quebecers needing to stay home between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m., with few exceptions. This included those who were experiencing homelessness, as Legault argued because of the cold, they should seek indoor shelter, and that “there is enough room available." Local advocates in the community, such as Nakuset, quickly spoke up in response to Legault’s comments, calling them “tone-deaf” for expecting homeless individuals to follow curfew. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Not only do individuals experiencing homelessness have to endure the very condition of homelessness, but also the discriminatory nature of the law. Nakuset’s fears were that police would fine homeless people, because they would be breaking the curfew. Geneviève Guilbault, Quebec's public security minister, stated the police would act with “appreciation” and “judgment” before ticketing a homeless person (the main goal ultimately to help find them a place). This example showcases the way in which the homeless population in Canada experiences discrimination, inadequate protective legislation, and lack of consideration when it comes to the law. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"While services like shelters and food programs tend to the immediate needs of individuals experiencing homelessness, it fails to prevent and transfer individuals out of this situation. Homeless individuals mainly spend time in public areas since they do not have access to a private space; however, some distinguished city officials view this as a “threat” to urban safety, and hence need the involvement of law enforcement officials. Gaetz (2013) stated, with regards to the “criminalization of homelessness”:","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"blockquote","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The key here is that people who occupy public spaces (because they lack private ones) and whose poverty is highly visible are subject to extra attention by the criminal justice system not so much for what they do, but for ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"who","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" they are and ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"where ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"they are (p. 338).","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Moreover, this can lead to the creation of new laws that indirectly target the homeless population by prohibiting them sleeping in public areas, sitting on sidewalks, and/or panhandling to ask for money. Increased enforcement of existing laws can also arise to maintain health and safety standards, but negatively impact the homeless. Attention must be paid to political and social justice issues as the execution of these regulatory practices are evidently influenced by underlying biases and affect the vulnerable members of our society.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Because of the harsh nature of such policing activities, it is not uncommon for homeless individuals to face incarceration even if they commit minor offences. Since they do not have a permanent address, they will likely be denied bail and thus remain in custody. Upon release, they usually either stay with family or friends temporarily, or go to a shelter, but inevitably, they do not have money or clean attire, leading some to quickly re-offend for the sole reason of trying to survive. These correctional facilities then become a provider of basic relief services for them as opposed to a place of restraint to crime.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What can be done instead?","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"To prevent these setbacks, policies should be set in place to provide homeless individuals access to suitable housing before they are released from custody. Discharge planning services should also be offered before and following their leave from correctional facilities to ensure that they can securely relocate. Additionally, upon their departure, they should be provided with clean clothes, an up-to-date list of community resources, and fares for public transport for an undisturbed transition back into society. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Key Takeaway","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Now that you have reached the end of this article, we hope that you were able to gain a new perspective on how the law, while seeming to exist for everyone’s protection, often does not work in favour of our homeless population. These individuals do not choose to remain homeless, but instead are oppressed by predisposed societal regulations. It is crucial that we as a community come together to support these vulnerable persons and dismantle existing prejudices for the betterment of society.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"References","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Gaetz, Stephen. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Youth Homelessness in Canada: Implications for Policy and Practice","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Canadian Homelessness Research Network, 2013.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Hulchanski, John David. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Finding Home: Policy Options for Addressing Homelessness in Canada","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Cities Centre, 2009.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/legault-homeless-curfew-covid-1.5864560","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/legault-homeless-curfew-covid-1.5864560"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" 


","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}
